What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Understanding different ways to push for social change and related empirical evidence on specific thematic issues.

I learned how to engage with empirical research as a means of addressing and understanding real world social and legal dilemmas. I gained an entirely new vocabulary and knowledge base that would serve me well in any capacity where I would be crafting policy, doing law, or just simply contributing to an organization.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: excellent teacher and materials. Improvement: could have included more discussion on the practice of conducting empirical evaluation of legal policies (methodology etc).

I thought Professor Tyler was absolutely a strength. He was clear and concise and his expectations were also never confusing. he curated a fascinating syllabus and challenged people to further their thinking by raising truly useful counter-examples and clarifications.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes -- fascinating material and an excellent teacher.
Most definitely. It is a fantastic course that gives you brilliant insight into legal psychology and unpacks the complexity of discussions that are frequently simplified.

I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone interested in cognitive science or political science or law. I think Professor Tyler's passion for social psychology as it pertains to the legal field is both infectious and necessary; if the class taught me anything it's that we need to learn more about how people think in order to better structure our society
